results.title: Personal Best
results.brief_description: Several young disabled people speak of the barriers caused by general lack of awareness of their needs, and by some people’s prejudices. Disabled people of all ages are then shown participating in a wide variety of activities. Achievement, at a personal level appropriate to the individual, is the dominant theme.

results.title: Persona = Diabolic women = Masks [DVD]
results.brief_description: An actress’s nervous breakdown occasions her deliberate withdrawal into speechlessness. As a consequence she appears to break down her nurse’s confident personality. However, “Persona” cannot be summarised in terms of conventional plot. It is a virtual monologue in which language is presented as fraudulent. In Susan Sontag’s words, it is “a powerful instance of the motif of exchange. The actress creates a void by her silence. The nurse, by speaking, falls into it.” It is possible to interpret the first half of the film as naturalistic drama but following the disruption of the ‘terrifying caesura’ in the middle (which, like the opening, operates on the principle of intensity, not Brechtian detachment), the level of reality of each event is ambiguous, unresolved. Cast includes: Bibi Andersson, Liv Ullmann, Gunnar Bjornstrand. Photography by Sven Nykvist. In Swedish with English subtitles.

results.creator_credit: L. Joseph Stone and United States. Office of Economic Opportunity
results.brief_description: Stresses the importance of the human relationships between infant and adult, and shows that in group care as well as at home there can be a considerable range of warmth and adequacy of relationship.

results.title: Persistent and finagling
results.creator_credit: Michael Rubbo, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The growing resolve of a group of Montreal women, members of STOP (Society To Overcome Pollution), to do something about air pollution by factories in their city led to a campaign to focus public attention on the problem. Despite rebuffs of every kind, they persisted until they were able to bring newspapers, radio and television to bear on their fight. What they accomplished, and how they went about it, will interest urban audiences.

results.title: Persian story
results.creator_credit: Ralph Keene, Film Producers Guild and Greenpark Productions
results.brief_description: Photographed during the last few months prior to British evacuation from Abadan, the film shows the magnitude of the Persian oil operations. Shows the barren nature of the countryside, the enormous amount of work done n developing the resources of the oil field, the extent of the pipelines across the desert and the refinery at Abadan, and something of the life of both Persian and British in the refinery city.

results.title: Persevere
results.creator_credit: John Vincent, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Soon after landing in South Vietnam, John Vincent was sent to Pleiku to serve as a Platoon Commander. In telling of his time in Pleiku, John considers the cultural assumptions he made and the importance of his training in military action.

results.title: Perpetual motion
results.creator_credit: Harry Robin and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description:
Uses several models of man’s attempts to create a perpetual motion machine to explore the laws of thermodynamics. Points out that energy must be continually added to any system to maintain orderly operation.
Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Permutations
results.brief_description:
An early example of computer generated animation; several hundred dots move about the screen according to a set of
instructions in a graphics program which were input into a
IBM digital computer and coloured by an optical printer.
‘Action sequences, proceeding from order to disorder and back to ordered patterning, suggest a parallel to harmonic phenomena of the musical scale … The effect is to subtly generate and resolve tension - which is similar to the primary emotional power of music composition’ (John Whitney).

results.title: Peripheral vision / O Yuki Conjugate
results.brief_description: Described as “an abstract environmental video for insomniacs” this video features the electronic music of O Yuki Conjugate and imagery accumulated and compiled by Andrew Hulme. The impression is of a moving abstract painting, of colours, shapes and textures which move across the screen in an endlessly moving display, with, now and then, the tantalising suggestion of an object or a person just at the edge of vision.

results.title: Peripheral Produce: all time greatest hits
results.brief_description: Peripheral Produce defines itself as a “as a propaganda machine that promotes underground cinematic endeavours.” It began as a monthly screening series of independent and experimental short film and video works in Portland, Oregon in 1996 and soon after set up a distribution arm to disseminate these works. This, their tenth release is a “best of” collection of works made between 1998 and 2002. “Getting stronger every day” explores the imaginative life of children in mundanely poignant tableaux where the spirit realm manifests in lo-tech effects and remembered TV movies. “Wustenspringmaus” is a quirky documentary about wily rodent of the title, also known as the gerbil. “The Subconscious art of graffiti removal” is a keen observation about visual aesthetics of graffiti removal that reveals how the destruction of one art form unwittingly creates another. “Stuffing” is a found footage video juxtaposing images to create humorous and absurd associations. In “Removed” an old pornographic film is manipulated using nail polish and bleach, to erase the image of the woman from the scene. “Election collectables” is a faux-recreation of a home shopping network where presidential candidates spruik collectables commemorating the 2000 elections. “N Judah 5:30” captures fleeting images of tired commuters. “Oona’s veil” is a study in celluloid decomposition using a strip of film from a screen test. “Crowdog” is a personal documentary in which the filmmaker recalls events that took place during the years in her teens when she stopped wearing shoes. “Buffalo Common” documents the dismantling of the ballistic missile industry in North Dakota - leaving the state to reconsider its already pessimistic future.
